advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www1.cts.ne.jp/~sato/hp/">Sato's Homepage</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a small advert from a french reseller "Vectron". The ad is dated november 1984 and the EXL-100 is sold for 3240fr. <br><br> The title says : "The french answer" </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> SEGA'S new hard keyboard and new hard disk drive, make Sega even harder to beat.<br> The very latest industry standard 3" diskettes store a massive 328K of information each desk, and operate at speeds far in excess of their older 5 1/4 inch counterparts. Sega's super control station will also enable you to connect to many other attachments such as business printers electronic typewriters even telephone moderns, through it's two additional I/0 ports, for RS232C and parallel interfaces. <br><br> Sega now boasts not only the most sophisticated and easy to learn basic language, the most incredible graphic capabilities, a sensational range of cartridge and cassette games, superb education and applications software written by and for New Zealanders, but also a very sophisticated, fast, small business system, with the state of the art Sega control station. Feel the difference, see the difference, compare the difference, and you too can enjoy the difference of Sega superiority.</font> <br><br> Notice that between numerous superlatives, the advertising agency mistook floppy disk for hard disk drive.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You hesitate between two standards."<br> "Rank Xerox doesn't."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 100 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MAGAZINE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gridcase made the cover of SVM (french magazine) in january 1985</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (OCT. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> HEATH CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>Extract from the 1961 Heathkit catalog</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VICTOR ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>with the original Victor design.<br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The Victor 9000. It's a desktop system computer designed to be a "cut above" the rest...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CMC INTERNATIONAL</strong></font><br><blockquote>It seems that the CMC Company (We have no more info about this company) used SuperBrain systems in which they added various hard disks, from 5 to 20 MB. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color ="#666666">The Altos ACS8000-6 series. It's a barrier breaker in every sense. Our entry level, single-user, hard-disk system with floppy backup is priced under $10,000...<br> ... With MP/M at the helm, your Altos system can support up to four simulteneous users with 48 KB RAM each plus 58 MB of Winchester storage and 4 MB of floppy backup. And that adds up to the first microcomputer to give you the power and performance of a minicomputer.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
After having invented the first IBM-compatible transportable computer, and having recorded half a billion dollars turnover, Compaq decided to launch its second portable AT clone. The system featured an 8 MHz processor and a 10 MB hard disk in a package 30% smaller and 20% lighter than previous PC model.
The general engineering idea behind this machine was to provide a cut-down IBM PC/AT clone with fewer expansion slots (5), a small hard disk and a floppy disc. This allowed Compaq to make the Portable II smaller and lighter without sacrificing too much specification.
Like many portable systems of the time, the keyboard attached to the front of the case and when the machine was ready for carrying, it was like a sewing machine.
The machine was supplied with 640 KB of RAM which was the maximum that could be fitted to the main board. However, RAM could be taken up to 2.1 MB by using a custom-designed expansion card.
Technically the Portable II gave its user more power than an IBM PC/AT for almost half the price. At the same time, Compaq delivered two desktop computers, the Deskpro PC/XT and Deskpro PC/AT, and two portable systems, the Portable/Plus PC/XT and the Portable 286 which was a full function PC/AT clone. _______________________
computer.keyboard: Full stroke 84-key with numeric keypad and 10 function keys
computer.media: 1/2 5.25'' 360 KB floppy disc drives, or 1 x FDD + 10 MB Hard disk
computer.name: Portable II
computer.ports: Serial, Parallel, external CGA monitor, Composite video
computer.power: Built-in 130 Watt switching power supply unit
computer.ram: 640 KB on board, up to 2.1 MB

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> RUNNING SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Portable II running the Compaq Diagnostic program.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CONNECTORS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sliding lids on either side of the casing cover the power switch and fan at left, and I/O ports at right (Colour and mono video outputs, serial and parallel ports).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under the plastic casing, the electronics is completely enclosed with a metallic cage. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>The mainboard is located below the CRT and drives.<br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Switching power supply unit<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Intel "Above Board" 2 MB RAM expansion<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> CGA video card<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> Multi-IO card - Floppy and HDD drives controller, serial and parallel ports<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Seagate 10 MB hard-disk drive.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> EXPANSION CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>From top to bottom:<br> • 2 MB above board<br> • CGA video card<br> • Multi-IO card</blockquote>

computer.text: 40 or 80 chars. x 25 lines (IBM CGA or monochrome modes)
